snippet.textDisplay: Sort of a add on to his video but I theorize that mecha is going through a phrase similar to the space age of the 60s. Much like that era the future seemed like a idealistic amazing thing, that we could make it to the moon meant we could make it anywhere. Mecha similarly, even in its more dark takes, always shows tech as a marvelous thing that anyone wishes they could be a part of, a sci fi fantasy all could enjoy. But, much like how when people realized they couldnt go to mars and grew out of sorts with that wistful future, the same is happening in our era, where with all the crazy problems we are dealing with right now, climate change, scarcity and the like. Its is much easier to get jaded and deflated in shows like these then in isekai, which at the very least gives you a fantasy of a world you know you could never go to, whereas in mecha it could be theoretically possible to make such cool machines but we are more likely to go extinct then make them, though that is my thesis and i am a westerner so wouldnt know asian demographics reasons for making less of this genre of media. .3.
snippet.textOriginal: Sort of a add on to his video but I theorize that mecha is going through a phrase similar to the space age of the 60s. But, much like how when people realized they couldnt go to mars and grew out of sorts with that wistful future, the same is happening in our era, where with all the crazy problems we are dealing with right now, climate change, scarcity and the like. snippet.textDisplay: If you ask me then its because there is little imagination or care on storytelling and world building. Just look at the mechs themselves, they look like Gundam ripoffs. They is nothing interesting about their technology, their construction, or even their operating systems and how they function. And conversely their world is also bland and uninspired. You could take them out of their own world and place them in any other and they would not stick out at all. People have forgotten how to dream and without dreaming you cannot make anything. They have spent so much time copying on what worked, mainly being Gundam and the super robots that defined anime early on, but in doing so they forgot how to dream new dreams, and it doesn't help that reality has surpassed those dreams without the laws of our reality as they so commonly do. Now we have liquid polymer aka liquid magnets, we can rearrange atoms now albeit slowly, we are beginning to make small steps in converting energy into matter, we solved the case of schrodinger's cat being able to now decide whether it is alive or dead, we have super impose atoms in order to determine their mass without background electromagnetic interference, we have froze light solid,  and many more such wonders that I am aware of that the scientific community knows and it is that community that are most likely to become mecha fans, but now reality has overcome the stagnant dream. Why must mechs be gaint? Why must they resemble humans? Why do they no longer act like robots and machines instead being indistinguishable from a person in movement?
snippet.textOriginal: If you ask me then its because there is little imagination or care on storytelling and world building. Just look at the mechs themselves, they look like Gundam ripoffs. They is nothing interesting about their technology, their construction, or even their operating systems and how they function. And conversely their world is also bland and uninspired. You could take them out of their own world and place them in any other and they would not stick out at all. People have forgotten how to dream and without dreaming you cannot make anything. They have spent so much time copying on what worked, mainly being Gundam and the super robots that defined anime early on, but in doing so they forgot how to dream new dreams, and it doesn't help that reality has surpassed those dreams without the laws of our reality as they so commonly do. Now we have liquid polymer aka liquid magnets, we can rearrange atoms now albeit slowly, we are beginning to make small steps in converting energy into matter, we solved the case of schrodinger's cat being able to now decide whether it is alive or dead, we have super impose atoms in order to determine their mass without background electromagnetic interference, we have froze light solid,  and many more such wonders that I am aware of that the scientific community knows and it is that community that are most likely to become mecha fans, but now reality has overcome the stagnant dream. Why must mechs be gaint? Why must they resemble humans? Why do they no longer act like robots and machines instead being indistinguishable from a person in movement?

snippet.textDisplay: While Mecha shows may have suffered this decade, trigger somewhat made up for it with Promare. I wouldn't describe it as solely Mecha, but moreso a celebration of trigger and what makes their shows (minus one) so good. Gurren lagann and kill la kill are the biggest influences, but it doesn't fail to remind you why you love their shows. The action is intense, the characters have great moments that are both funny and inspiring, and the visuals play into a lot of the plot as well. While it may be over the top and ridiculous at times, ultimately it's a wonderful experience for any fan of trigger, and stands as a pillar of inspriation for the Mecha genre.
snippet.textOriginal: While Mecha shows may have suffered this decade, trigger somewhat made up for it with Promare. I wouldn't describe it as solely Mecha, but moreso a celebration of trigger and what makes their shows (minus one) so good. Gurren lagann and kill la kill are the biggest influences, but it doesn't fail to remind you why you love their shows. The action is intense, the characters have great moments that are both funny and inspiring, and the visuals play into a lot of the plot as well. While it may be over the top and ridiculous at times, ultimately it's a wonderful experience for any fan of trigger, and stands as a pillar of inspriation for the Mecha genre.

snippet.textDisplay:
I kind of appreciate that that macross is like a half idol half meccha hybrid anime cause its the franchise that pulled me into meccha in the first place.
I started off watching anime’s like idolmaster and love live and never would have watched evangelion or code geass if I hadn’t gotten into macross first.
Macross was a good stepping stone for me since it had the singing anime girls that I was used to and comfortable with but also the action and interesting plot that idol anime’s are missing.

snippet.textDisplay:
As a purist mecha fan...

I think you greatly underestimate the impact of "Gundam space africa"... or rather, Iron blooded orphans.

It was controversial for touching some sensitive topics (such as the use of slaves/child soldiers in wars... and actual harems)

But if you're willing actually get into the thought experiment and go with...

Its hands down the BEST gundam serie... like ... ever.

The animation are great, the music is iconic and best of all... the story is the most insane emitionnal roller caster I've gotten into.

Like seriously, its a new timeline too! No need to have any past knowledge of the franchise!
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly, I never got into Mecha. Call me insane, but giant robots never interested me. Sure, as a concept they're cool, but giant robots duking it out causes some problems in my opinion.
First, when theres a fight scene, Mecha makes conveying emotions harder. In a normal fight, you can show the combatants facial expressions. They show their character, react to their opponent and convey how healthy they are just through visual cues.
In a mecha on the other hand, you have to cut to another shot to show the same thing, casue the pilot sits in a dark room and shouts at the screens in front of him. It kills the momentum.
Additionally, I have never seen a mecha battle animated better than a regular one. The design and size of most mechs makes it so much harder to give them believable motion and physics.
Also, any other type of vehicle design is gotta be easier to produce and steer than a mecha. Sure the rule of cool is a thing, but I that's where the last argument comes in:
If I want dudes throwing laser blasts and explosives at each other, I dont need it to be excused by a high-tech robot. Gimme One-Punch Man, Dragon Ball, Fate/Zero and give me god damn Avengers. None of those need mechas to have any of this.
I didnt watch Code Geass because of the giant robots, I watched it DESPITE of it.
snippet.textOriginal:
Honestly, I never got into Mecha. Call me insane, but giant robots never interested me. Sure, as a concept they're cool, but giant robots duking it out causes some problems in my opinion. 
First, when theres a fight scene, Mecha makes conveying emotions harder. In a normal fight, you can show the combatants facial expressions. They show their character, react to their opponent and convey how healthy they are just through visual cues. 
In a mecha on the other hand, you have to cut to another shot to show the same thing, casue the pilot sits in a dark room and shouts at the screens in front of him. It kills the momentum. 
Additionally, I have never seen a mecha battle animated better than a regular one. The design and size of most mechs makes it so much harder to give them believable motion and physics.
Also, any other type of vehicle design is gotta be easier to produce and steer than a mecha. Sure the rule of cool is a thing, but I that's where the last argument comes in:
If I want dudes throwing laser blasts and explosives at each other, I dont need it to be excused by a high-tech robot. Gimme One-Punch Man, Dragon Ball, Fate/Zero and give me god damn Avengers. None of those need mechas to have any of this. 
I didnt watch Code Geass because of the giant robots, I watched it DESPITE of it.

snippet.textDisplay: Something about Mecha anime I heard was that Mecha in kind of the random genre in anime. Mecha anime are never really about the Mecha, they are usually about something different. Like, Evangelion is about trying to move forward in a world that is less fun. Code Geass is a wannabe Death Note mixed with high school drama everybody forgot about. Gurren Lagann is about becoming a fucking man!! See what I mean? It's not about the Mecha. Mecha are just giant robots, and they are badass.
snippet.textOriginal: Something about Mecha anime I heard was that Mecha in kind of the random genre in anime. Mecha anime are never really about the Mecha, they are usually about something different. Like, Evangelion is about trying to move forward in a world that is less fun. Code Geass is a wannabe Death Note mixed with high school drama everybody forgot about. Gurren Lagann is about becoming a fucking man!! See what I mean? It's not about the Mecha. Mecha are just giant robots, and they are badass.

snippet.textDisplay: While I know it isn't a true addition to the anime mecha genre (in my eyes it is, but I get it if others don't agree). I have to mention my favorite mecha series recently has to be gen:LOCK. It is so visually stunning and the storyline is great, and I think it just got renewed for season two with HBO and Rooster Teeth forming a partnership with it. Just my opinion, but I loved it, and the opening song is kick ass.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think another big issue is that Mecha anime are insanely expensive to make, especially if everything is fully animated and not with CGI. With the amount of fight scenes and intensive action, a lot of movement and detail is required, which probably digs a lot into a budget. So because of this, I think it wouldn’t be too far fetched to say that because of the intensive production costs required for mecha anime, studios or directors are afraid of touching the genre because if they cannot make a good, popular product, then they are deep trouble.

Gundam is able to do it mainly because of the fact they earn money from merchandise as well. Gunpla, I think, is largely responsible for why Gundam is able to still make nearly or completely fully animated Gundam anime. On the other hand, a random mecha anime would have to rely on solely the sales of the anime, and if they anime was bad or not received poorly, then they have no real other way to recuperate their losses.
snippet.textOriginal:
I think another big issue is that Mecha anime are insanely expensive to make, especially if everything is fully animated and not with CGI. With the amount of fight scenes and intensive action, a lot of movement and detail is required, which probably digs a lot into a budget. So because of this, I think it wouldn’t be too far fetched to say that because of the intensive production costs required for mecha anime, studios or directors are afraid of touching the genre because if they cannot make a good, popular product, then they are deep trouble.

Gundam is able to do it mainly because of the fact they earn money from merchandise as well. Gunpla, I think, is largely responsible for why Gundam is able to still make nearly or completely fully animated Gundam anime. On the other hand, a random mecha anime would have to rely on solely the sales of the anime, and if they anime was bad or not received poorly, then they have no real other way to recuperate their losses.

It's definitely worth the watch weather you want a mecha show, a more dark and depressing show or are into history and alternate history.

snippet.textDisplay: I would like to argue that Gundam Build Fighters (the first series) is a stellar anime for casual mecha fans. It is actually what got me into the Gundam series as a whole, mostly to see just where some of the cool mechs came from, as well as hoping that something might capture the same joy I had when watching Build Fighters.
snippet.textOriginal: I would like to argue that Gundam Build Fighters (the first series) is a stellar anime for casual mecha fans. It is actually what got me into the Gundam series as a whole, mostly to see just where some of the cool mechs came from, as well as hoping that something might capture the same joy I had when watching Build Fighters.

snippet.textDisplay:
Summary:
- Mecha isn't special anymore in the 2010s
- Gotten a bad rep from series that started off strong but turned into trainwrecks: guilty crown, franxx, a/z, valvrave, e7 ao etc.
- Series are stuck between appealing to existing fans and making things accessible for new viewers: Gundam, code geass, etc.
snippet.textOriginal:
Summary:
- Mecha isn't special anymore in the 2010s
- Gotten a bad rep from series that started off strong but turned into trainwrecks: guilty crown, franxx, a/z, valvrave, e7 ao etc. 
- Series are stuck between appealing to existing fans and making things accessible for new viewers: Gundam, code geass, etc.
